results.title: What Would the Cast of ‘Knock at the Cabin’ Do?
results.abstract: In an interview, the stars of M. Night Shyamalan’s film address the soul-searching questions posed to their characters.

results.title: Disney’s Iger Returns to Familiar Stage, but With Different Challenges
results.abstract: The company reports quarterly earnings on Wednesday, and Wall Street is expecting it to lay out a new streaming strategy and operating structure.

results.title: How to Turn a Good Cry Into Good Cinema
results.abstract: Bringing a great crying scene to the big screen requires a combination of craft and empathy. This is how three recent movies — “Close,” “Babylon” and “The Woman King” — pulled it off.

results.title: What Will It Take to Trust M. Night Shyamalan?
results.abstract: The director, whose latest is “Knock at the Cabin,” has been working to regain audience faith, one B-movie at a time.

results.abstract: Kyle Edward Ball, the filmmaker behind “Skinamarink,” and Robbie Banfitch, who made “The Outwaters,” talk about their creepy, buzzy movies.

results.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a pandemic-inspired killer, a trance-induced massacre and a bloodthirsty little boy.

results.title: How Much to See a Movie at AMC? It Will Soon Depend Where You Sit.
results.abstract: By the end of 2023, the movie theater chain will offer tickets at three different price tiers, with middle seats costing the most. You’ll pay less if you like the front row.

multimedia.caption: AMC said its new pricing system would not be applied to tickets for discounted Tuesday screenings or showings before 4 p.m.
multimedia.copyright: Gabby Jones for The New York Times

results.title: Melinda Dillon, 2-Time Oscar Nominee, Is Dead at 83
results.abstract: She was a Broadway star at 23 and then quit acting, but later re-emerged in films like “Close Encounters of the Third Kind” and “A Christmas Story.”
des_facet: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Melinda Dillon, left, with Cary Guffey in the 1977 Steven Spielberg film “Close Encounters of the Third Kind.” Ms. Dillon received an Oscar nomination for her performance.
Melinda Dillon, left, with Cary Guffey in the 1977 Steven Spielberg film “Close Encounters of the Third Kind.” Ms. Dillon received an Oscar nomination for her performance.

results.title: Reflections on Star Quality From a Golden Age of ‘Junk TV’
results.abstract: In a new memoir, a longtime casting director revels in memories of a bygone Hollywood, matching actors with the roles that made them stars.
des_facet: Sex, Drugs & Pilot Season: Confessions of a Casting Director (Book)

multimedia.caption: For the lead role of “The Boy in the Plastic Bubble,” the casting director Joel Thurm tapped a young John Travolta, an actor he would turn to again for the hit film adaptation of “Grease.”
For the lead role of “The Boy in the Plastic Bubble,” the casting director Joel Thurm tapped a young John Travolta, an actor he would turn to again for the hit film adaptation of “Grease.”

results.title: Claudia Cardinale: 6 Decades in the Movies
results.abstract: Ahead of a MoMA retrospective, the actress reflected on her career, which includes over 100 films and many classics of Italian cinema.

results.title: ‘Godland’ Review: Another of God’s Lonely Men Goes Amok (Spiritually)
results.abstract: In this striking drama set in the late 19th century, a Danish priest travels to Iceland and is gradually undone by a world he can’t understand.

multimedia.caption: “Godland” tracks a priest, Lucas (an effective Elliott Crosset Hove), as he trudges across Iceland.
“Godland” tracks a priest, Lucas (an effective Elliott Crosset Hove), as he trudges across Iceland.

results.title: ‘Una Vita Difficile’ Review: Life Comes at You Fast
results.abstract: Alberto Sordi stars as an idealistic Italian Everyman caught up in a changing postwar world in this rediscovered comedy from the ’60s.

results.title: ‘The Blind Man Who Did Not Want to See Titanic’ Review: Just Like the Movies
results.abstract: In this wry Finnish drama, a disabled man embarks on a journey to visit his girlfriend, encountering inaccessible infrastructure and evil goons along the way.

multimedia.caption: In “The Blind Man Who Did Not Want to See Titanic,” Jaakko (Petri Poikolainen) is blind and uses a wheelchair, but his disability is not his defining characteristic.

results.title: ‘Full Time’ Review: No Rest for the Working Girl
results.abstract: A breathlessly tense portrait of modern labor, this French drama stars Laure Calamy as a single mother who hits her breaking point during a nationwide strike.

results.title: ‘Body Parts’ Review: Even Sex Scenes Have Rules
results.abstract: The documentary features performers and filmmakers discussing onscreen nudity and sex, but offers little on the subject of sexual exploitation.

multimedia.caption: In “Body Parts,” interview subjects discuss nudity riders, contractual documents that specify what acts an actor is willing to perform.
In “Body Parts,” interview subjects discuss nudity riders, contractual documents that specify what acts an actor is willing to perform.

results.title: ‘Love in the Time of Fentanyl’ Review: Heartbreak, Death and Hope in Vancouver
results.abstract: To combat the overdose crisis, a group that includes former and current users open a safe consumption site where shooting up does not have to mean death.
des_facet: Love in the Time of Fentanyl (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Drug users can safely consume their drugs at the Overdose Prevention Society, in Vancouver, where drugs are tested for fentanyl. They talk openly about what led them to start using, and about the challenges of quitting.

Drug users can safely consume their drugs at the Overdose Prevention Society, in Vancouver, where drugs are tested for fentanyl. They talk openly about what led them to start using, and about the challenges of quitting.

results.title: ‘The Locksmith’ Review: A Botched Job
results.abstract: Ryan Phillippe plays a lock picker trying to escape his past in this clunky, clichéd crime thriller.

Miller (Ryan Phillippe) spends a decade in prison after being framed for his friend’s murder in “The Locksmith,” directed by Nicolas Harvard.

results.title: ‘A Lot of Nothing’ Review: The Cop Next Door
results.abstract: Mo McRae’s feature debut, about a well-off Black couple and their white neighbor, is more of a trauma drama than a satirical thriller.

multimedia.caption: From left, Y’lan Noel, Cleopatra Coleman, Lex Scott Davis and Shamier Anderson in “A Lot of Nothing.”

results.title: ‘80 for Brady’ Review: Remember These Titans
results.abstract: This stubbornly charming romp starring Lily Tomlin, Jane Fonda, Sally Field and Rita Moreno is inspired by the story of a real group of female friends with a love for Tom Brady and the New England Patriots.

results.title: Kerry Condon: ‘I Don’t Think Anything Has Ever Come Easy to Me’
results.abstract: An ardent animal lover, the supporting actress Oscar nominee for “The Banshees of Inisherin” channeled grief from her dog’s death into her performance.

multimedia.caption: Kerry Condon described the nomination as “a dream come true.” She said, “I don’t think there’s anything wrong with admitting that you’re ambitious.”
multimedia.copyright: Ariel Fisher for The New York Times

results.title: Oscar Isaac, Rachel Brosnahan and the Draw of a Neglected Hansberry Play
results.abstract: The first major New York revival of “The Sign in Sidney Brustein’s Window,” Lorraine Hansberry’s 1964 Broadway play, comes to BAM this month. What took so long?
des_facet: The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window (Play)

multimedia.caption: “We are revisiting a huge conversation right now about white apathy and the consequences of that in our political system and world,” Rachel Brosnahan said. Lorraine Hansberry “explores that with such nuance in this play.”
multimedia.copyright: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

results.title: Academy Won’t Rescind Best Actress Nomination
results.abstract: The organization investigated whether an Oscars campaign for the “To Leslie” actress Andrea Riseborough had violated rules.

multimedia.caption: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences did say it discovered “social media and outreach campaigning tactics” on behalf of Andrea Riseborough that “caused concern.”

results.title: More Than Shirley: Cindy Williams’s 6 Best Moments Onscreen
results.abstract: Her comedic work in “Laverne & Shirley” was career-defining. But the actress had other chops, too. Here’s a look at some of her best work and where to see it.

multimedia.caption: Cindy Williams, right (with Penny Marshall), was best known for her role as Shirley Feeney, an unmarried blue-collar worker in Milwaukee, in “Laverne & Shirley.”
multimedia.copyright: ABC Photo Archives/Disney General Entertainment Content, via Getty Images
